title: 106_s382
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" have national significance as preserved examples of American history during the Cold War. The facilities symbolize dedication and preparedness exhibited by Air Force missileers in remote locations. The Act aims to preserve and interpret these structures for future generations and highlight the historical role of the Minuteman II missile defense system. The Act aims to preserve and interpret the structures associated with the Minuteman II missile defense system for future generations. It also seeks to highlight the historical role of the system in America's strategic commitment to world peace during the Cold War. Additionally, it complements interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established to preserve structures related to the Minuteman II missile defense system and highlight its historical significance during the Cold War. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota is established as part of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities. The site includes the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Facilities, with a map available for public inspection. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to make adjustments to the site's boundaries. The Secretary of the Interior can make minor adjustments to the boundary of the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site. The site will be administered in accordance with relevant laws and the Secretary will consult with other agencies to ensure compliance. Cooperative agreements may be entered into by the Secretary. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site through donation, purchase, or exchange, but not if contaminated with hazardous substances. The Secretary may acquire South Dakota land by donation or exchange. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years, including evaluation of visitor facility locations and boundary modifications. The Secretary can acquire South Dakota land for a visitor facility and administrative site, modifying the historic site's boundary. Coordination with Badlands National Park is considered for administrative functions. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the maintenance and preservation of a historic site. The Secretary of the Air Force is required to transfer funds for this purpose from the Air Force budget. The Legacy Resource Management Program's funds are not affected by this Act.
